item.title: Trial runs for fascism are in full flow
item.description:
This article by Fintan O‚ÄôToole in The Irish Times is a few weeks old now, but I keep thinking about it.

Fascism doesn‚Äôt arise suddenly in an existing democracy. It is not easy to get people to give up their ideas of freedom and civility. You have to do trial runs that, if they are done well, serve two purposes. They get people used to something they may initially recoil from; and they allow you to refine and calibrate. This is what is happening now and we would be fools not to see it.

Mr. O‚ÄôToole lays out a simple and convincing argument outlining ideas that I have been mulling over in my head, but not writing much about, since Trump‚Äôs election on November 8, 2016. What has happened‚Äîat an accelerating pace, I think, since last year‚Äîis that the bounds of what is considered normal have been stretched so far into what was previously outrageous that I fear there is no going back. If Trump and the Republican Party are proving that the U.S. president is above the law, and that much of what governed the government was merely tradition, which is disposable for political expediency, then what, if anything, will constrain the power and the actions of future U.S. presidents?
Oh! I‚Äôm getting a Microsoft Office update this morning. I wonder what office suites were like in the year 2016‚Ä¶
I have pared back my Twitter following list to Lin-Manuel Miranda and Ole Begemann, which is sometimes weird and sometimes delightful, the few moments per week I check in on them.

I‚Äôm super pleased listening to these V-Moda Crossfade 2 Codex Edition headphones all day at work, over Bluetooth. (Wireless use is pretty rare for me.) Great sound. Great isolation. The top of my head is a little sore from the headband, though. (They are kind of heavy.) üéß

I checked out the new MacBook Pros at the Apple Store. The new keyboard looks (feels) like a winner to me. It is quieter, and there‚Äôs a good chance it won‚Äôt have the same reliability problem as the prior generation. I would prefer a 15‚Äù one without the TouchBar, though, but don‚Äôt plan to buy one until my 2015 rMBP breaks or is no longer supported.

Our appointment for family photos at the park got canceled today due to heavy rain. We ended up shopping and eating pancakes instead. Not a bad trade-off for the day, but I would have liked to have the photos later.

I both love and hate articles like ‚ÄúThe New York Yankees Are a Moral Abomination‚Äù. Handwringing, declinist arguments about baseball are almost as old as baseball itself. ‚ÄúBaseball is in decline‚Äù is part of its brand‚Äîpart that needs to go away, I think.

Baseball is awesome. The players are very skillful, play a game that doesn‚Äôt involve hurting each other, and legitimately appear to be enjoying themselves.

I started replaying Bastion on my IPad Pro tonight. I bought it years ago and never finished it. I‚Äôm using a controller and headphones this time around, which improve the experience. I‚Äôm better at combat than I used to be, but a lot worse at the proving grounds challenges.
If I was smart, I would save $100/month for a new MacBook every 4 years or so. I am not smart.

item.description:
No kidding, The New Yorker, no kidding:

For years, conservatives complained about activist liberal judges making it up as they went along. Today, they are the activists. Under the guise of ‚Äúoriginalism,‚Äù they are rewriting the nation‚Äôs laws to further the reactionary political agenda of the Republican Party and its biggest donors.

Note the scare quotes around ‚Äúoriginalism‚Äù. It, like all the other -ism words we throw around‚Äîconservatism, liberalism, socialism‚Äî is completely devoid of meaning.

item.title: Tower 3.0's release and new pricing model
item.description:
I have been beta testing Tower 3.0, which is a very nice Git GUI client, for the past few months. The team behind it have just announced that the version 3.0 is complete. I was ready last week to purchase the software at its old price, which would be a one-time purchase of $79, but Tower has also announced that it is moving to subscription pricing for version 3.

Switching from paid-up-front to subscription-based is somewhat controversial. I, for one, am all for software subscriptions, so I support the developers‚Äô decision. However, their decision has signaled that Tower is not for me. Even with the generous 50% discount for the first year that they have offered me, as a beta tester, the developers have priced me out of their product. For a professional, making a living from their software, the subscription cost for an important workplace tool is merely a drop in the bucket. But for me, a hobbyist developer who charges for my apps to cover my costs, I don‚Äôt make nearly enough money from my apps to justify paying more than a couple dollars per month for a Git client.

Git‚Äôs command line tools and Atlassian‚Äôs SourceTree client are free to use. I will be back to using SourceTree‚Äîwhich which is free, full-featured, but not as well polished as Tower‚Äîshortly. Thanks to the Tower team for allowing me to beta test their software. I wish them the best of luck.
I have learned a heck of a lot about clean iOS app architecture from Dave Delong‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Better MVC‚Äù series.

I‚Äôm thinking of trading in my V-Moda Crossfade 2‚Äôs plus $100 to upgrade to thier Codex edition, which are the same headphones plus AAC and aptX support over Bluetooth. The better codecs will make them useful longer, like when the Lightning port goes away.
